stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on developing the 'Space City' level of RTYI. His focus was on world-building and visual design, including ideating a gramophone-shaped concert hall, creating a glowing walkway with custom lighting, and modeling a placeholder for a flying taxi. He also engaged in a lengthy discussion about the technical merits and downsides of a potential PC port.

development_findings.summary: The space city level features narrative progression where defeating the boss changes the level, causing Shy Guys to emerge and operate flying car taxis that the player can then use for transportation.
development_findings.quote: In the first act you can't really get anywhere, because all the shy guys in this level are scared and they're hiding in their houses. And then during the second act, after you beat the boss, the shy guys are out and they're gonna drive these cars here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is creating a large YouTube video documentary (approx. 45 mins) about all the shaders in the original Mario 64, noting that the shaders for the title screen's Mario head were 'months or years ahead' of the main game's.
To solve a visual problem with lamps clipping through the floor, Kaze decided to flip them upside down, turning them into uplights that create a unique visual style for a walkway.
development_findings.quote: What if we turn them upside down the lights? And we just like put them on the floor And then they shine light upwards would that look good do you think?

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working on a 'space city' level (Course 14) which will feature a gramophone-shaped concert hall and a flying taxi service to cross an impassable gap.
Kaze's development workflow involves completing the core platforming and gameplay mechanics for a level before circling back to polish the visuals.
development_findings.quote: The platforming for the first star done we're still working on the visuals right now I'm trying to like get all the platforming done and then afterwards maybe polish up the visuals a little bit.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a fake reflection effect on a wall by moving a star texture based on the camera's position, but decided against moving the entire skybox as it would be too disorienting for the player.
Kaze determined that a platforming section in a snow level was too difficult and needed to be redesigned to be easier, especially since the player cannot be punished by falling off.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration when fans qualify praise by mentioning his lack of budget and solo work, as he feels it diminishes the work's inherent quality and makes his life more difficult.
context_findings.quote: I hate when people look at my stuff. And they're like it's impressive. And then someone else always says. Oh but he has no budget. And he works alone. And I'm just like. I have no budget. And I work alone. Isn't that like making me look bad?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes a key principle of modern game design is to create an experience that feels open and non-linear to the player, even if its underlying structure is linear.
context_findings.quote: I think that's the key to modern game design you want to make something that is linear, but isn't it?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong negative stance on a potential PC port of RTYI, believing it offers no real advantages over modern emulation with plugins like RT64 and would only create a support headache for him.
context_findings.quote: If I had the ability to just like slip my fingers and the PC port would be out of existence, I would do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies that ROM hacking is no longer his full-time profession as of 2022; he has a separate programming job and considers this project a 'second full-time job' supported by Patreon and YouTube revenue.
context_findings.quote: This is not my full-time job anymore. So kinda it is a hobby, but also it's more like a part-time job on top of my full-time job. Or my second full-time job.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a nuanced aspect of his online persona, explaining that he enjoys playfully criticizing things but feels uncomfortable when others agree, as he prefers a dynamic of debate rather than creating an echo chamber.
context_findings.quote: I like hating on things, but I don't like if other people join me and hating on those things. Because then I feel like a bully. So like, I don't actually want you to agree with me that Conker's Bad Fur Day is bad. I want you to like, defend it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze openly discussed his channel's finances, stating he made $940 from YouTube in a month, paid his editor $500, and relies on Patreon for the majority of his project income.
Kaze notes his YouTube videos have evolved into 'computer science lectures in disguise' and hopes his upcoming, more visual video on shaders will be more approachable for a wider audience.

biobak.summary: Biobak's role is to polish Kaze's 3D models and contribute new ideas and concepts to the game's art direction.
biobak.quote: Biobak goes over my models. After I'm done. And polishes them up. Brings a lot of ideas. And new concepts to the table.

biobak.summary: Kaze expresses trust and reliance on Biobak to fix or improve his placeholder 3D modeling work.
biobak.quote: We got Biobak. Biobak will bail me out.

badub.summary: Badub is confirmed to be the composer for the project's music.

zeina.summary: Zeina contributed the concept art for the 'mutant Yoshi' boss for the space city level.
zeina.quote: This was her idea for the mutant Yoshi. That's the boss enemy here.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the Peach model for a snow level and was expected to also do the animations for it.
zeina.quote: You made this Peach by the way, if you don't remember, I think you also wanted to do the animation so I left that for you.

key_stories.title: The Upside-Down Lights
key_stories.summary: Faced with ugly clipping lamps, Kaze creatively solved the problem by flipping them upside down to act as floor-based uplights. This required a quick dive into the code to fix the light's direction, resulting in a unique visual element for the level.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was unhappy with how the default lamps looked clipping into the floor of the space city level and had no obvious alternative surfaces to attach them to.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed the idea of inverting the lamps. He then implemented it, discovering the light's direction vector was now incorrect. He used debug code to isolate and fix the directional issue, proving the concept worked.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully programmed the lights to be placed on the floor shining upwards. The effect worked as intended, with the light correctly illuminating Mario, creating a unique and functional visual solution.
key_stories.key_quote: What if we turn them upside down the lights? And we just like put them on the floor And then they shine light upwards would that look good do you think?

key_stories.title: The Case Against a PC Port
key_stories.summary: When confronted with the idea of a PC port, Kaze articulated a strong and detailed opposition. He argued against its technical necessity and expressed a deep-seated desire to avoid the community management nightmare he believes it would create, vowing to have no part in it.
key_stories.challenge: Fans and other developers frequently ask about or propose creating a PC port of RTYI, an idea Kaze is fundamentally opposed to.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically debunked the supposed advantages of a PC port, arguing that high FPS and widescreen are achievable via modern emulation (RT64). He expressed deep frustration with the repetitive questioning and the potential for a flood of bug reports for something he doesn't support.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze firmly established his position, stating he will have nothing to do with any PC port. He believes it is technically redundant, likely incompatible with his custom work, and would be a source of endless community support headaches.
key_stories.key_quote: If I had the ability to just like slip my fingers and the PC port would be out of existence, I would do it. That's where I'm at.

key_stories.title: Modeling the Flying Car
key_stories.summary: While developing a flying car asset, Kaze demonstrated the team's workflow. He created a rough, functional 3D model, but explicitly stated he was relying on his artist, Biobak, to perform the final polish and make it look good, showcasing their collaborative dependency.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze is creating a flying car model for the space city level but struggles with the 3D modeling, particularly creating a sleek design and appropriate details like a grill.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted to model the car, trying different shapes to reduce polycount while maintaining a sleek look. He searched through his texture assets to find a suitable grill texture. Acknowledging his modeling limitations, he decided his role was to create the basic form and function, leaving the artistic polish to a specialist on the team.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a functional, but rough, placeholder model for the flying car. He is content to leave it in a semi-finished state, trusting that his teammate Biobak will later refine and polish it into a final asset.
key_stories.key_quote: This is going to look bad. But it's fine, it's fine. We got Biobak. Biobak will bail me out.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that what he pays team members like Biobak is not fair for their amount of work, but that it's also not fair for his own, citing the low profitability of ROM hacking. He relies on Patreon for the majority of his income for the project.
questions: How do you structure the finances for a passion project of this scale?
Is it a revenue-share model from Patreon, or do you pay fixed rates?
How does this financial reality impact team morale, the project's scope, and your relationships with your contributors?

open_questions.context: Kaze showed concept art for a 'mutant Yoshi' boss created by Zeina, his spouse. He also mentioned a Peach model made by her that he was leaving for her to animate.
questions: How deeply is Zeina involved in the creative process beyond these specific examples?
What does the collaborative process between you two look like?
How do you navigate the dynamic of being both partners in life and creative collaborators on a demanding project?

open_questions.topic: Influence of Shader Research on RTYI
open_questions.context: Kaze is creating a 45-minute YouTube video explaining every shader in the original SM64. He was particularly impressed by the work of Goddard on the intro screen, calling it years ahead of the main dev team.
questions: What specific discoveries from your deep-dive into the original shaders have been directly applied to RTYI?
Did analyzing Goddard's advanced techniques inspire any new visual effects or optimizations in your own engine?
How has this research changed your perspective on the original developers' achievements and limitations?

open_questions.context: A community member named Alexado offered to create a PC port. Kaze gave a reluctant 'go for it' before explaining in detail why he personally is against the idea and wants nothing to do with it.
questions: What is your official stance if the community proceeds with a PC port against your preference?
What are your biggest fears about an unauthorized port? Is it about quality control, misrepresentation of your work, or the user support burden?
Would you publicly disavow it, or simply ignore it?
